titleStmt.title: DNA methylation within melatonin receptor 1A (MTNR1A) mediates paternally transmitted genetic variant effect on asthma plus rhinitis

analytic.title: DNA methylation within melatonin receptor 1A (MTNR1A) mediates paternally transmitted genetic variant effect on asthma plus rhinitis

biblStruct.note: Received for publication June 9, 2015; revised November 10, 2015; accepted for publication December 15, 2015. Available online March 30, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Background: Asthma and allergic rhinitis (AR) are common allergic comorbidities with a strong genetic component in which epigenetic mechanisms might be involved.
Objective: We aimed to identify novel risk loci for asthma and AR while accounting for parent-of-origin effect.

Methods: We performed a series of genetic analyses, taking into account the parent-of-origin effect in families ascertained through asthma: (1) genome-wide linkage scan of asthma and AR in 615 European families, (2) association analysis with 1233 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) covering the significant linkage region in 162 French Epidemiological Study on the Genetics and Environment of Asthma families with replication in 154 Canadian Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean asthma study families, and (3) association analysis of disease and significant SNPs with DNA methylation (DNAm) at CpG sites in 40 Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean asthma study families.
Results: We detected a significant paternal linkage of the 4q35 region to asthma and allergic rhinitis comorbidity (AAR; P 5 7.2 3 10 25 ).

Association analysis in this region showed strong evidence for the effect of the paternally inherited G allele of rs10009104 on AAR (P 5 1.1 3 10 25 , reaching the multipletesting corrected threshold).
This paternally inherited allele was also significantly associated with DNAm levels at the cg02303933 site (P 5 1.7 3 10 24 ).
Differential DNAm at this site was found to mediate the identified SNP-AAR association.

Conclusion: By integrating genetic and epigenetic data, we identified that a differentially methylated CpG site within the melatonin receptor 1A (MTNR1A) gene mediates the effect of a paternally transmitted genetic variant on the comorbidity of asthma and AR.
This study provides a novel insight into the role of epigenetic mechanisms in patients with allergic respiratory diseases.
association studies (GWASs) have been successful in identifying loci associated with asthma and AR, with a number of loci shared by both diseases. 5,6

A few genetic studies have examined asthma and AR comorbidities and led to the identification of new loci that were not detected when they were analyzed separately; these include ZBTB10, CLEC16A, and NFIA genes. 7,8

espite the success of GWASs for discovering common risk alleles associated with asthma, AR, or both, the genetic factors identified to date account only for a small part of the genetic component of these diseases. 1
Sources of this hidden heritability might include epigenetic mechanisms, such as DNA methylation (DNAm).
Epigenetic modifications are heritable changes influencing gene expression without alteration of the underlying DNA sequence.
Several lines of evidence support a role for epigenetics in asthma and allergy, which are immune-mediated diseases characterized by a T H 2-type immune response. 9
Epigenetic mechanisms are known to play a role in T-cell differentiation and regulation. 10
Moreover, environmental factors associated with asthma and allergy have been reported to induce epigenetic changes in experimental settings. 10

The importance of epigenetics in allergy-related diseases has been recently evidenced in human subjects by using an epigenome-wide association study of total IgE levels, where DNAm at 3 CpG sites was found to account for 13% of IgE variation, which is 10-fold higher than that accounted for by GWAS single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). 11

DNAm can cause partial or complete silencing of 1 parental allele (imprinting) at a specific locus and can lead to an effect of that polymorphism on disease in offspring that differs according to the parental origin (paternal or maternal) of the allele (parent-of-origin [POO] effect).

The goal of the present study was to identify novel risk loci for allergic diseases defined by asthma, AR, and asthma and allergic rhinitis comorbidity (AAR) through a positional cloning approach taking into account the POO effect and to determine whether the effect of associated SNPs is mediated by DNAm.

For that purpose, we developed a 3-step analysis strategy in family samples ascertained through asthma: (1) genome-wide linkage scan of asthma, AR, and AAR in 3 European family data sets; (2) association analysis of SNPs covering the significant linkage region in the French Epidemiological Study on the Genetics and Environment of Asthma (EGEA) discovery data set with validation in a French Canadian data set; and (3) association analyses of DNAm levels with both genetic variants and disease, followed by the causal inference test (CIT).
The study design is described in Fig E1 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org.

The first step consisted of a genome-wide linkage analysis of allergic diseases conducted in 615 families from 3 independent European family samples: EGEA, 12 the Medical Research Council Asthma UK National family collection, 13 and Italian families. 14
3][14] Asthma was based on a physician's diagnosis and international standardized questionnaires.
AR was defined by the report of at least 1 of the following symptoms: sneezing or runny nose to hay/flowers, animals, or dust.
AAR was defined as the coexistence of the 2 diseases (asthma and AR) in the same subject.
Details on study characteristics and phenotype definitions are provided in the Methods section and Table E1 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org.
In the second step the region of linkage found significantly linked to AAR in the presence of the POO effect was explored for association in the EGEA study.
This study was the only one of the 3 data sets used for linkage analysis that had genotyped SNPs in both parents and offspring, thus allowing testing for the POO effect.

After applying stringent quality control (QC) criteria, there were 531 family members belonging to 162 families with at least 1 offspring with AAR and 2 genotyped parents (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details).

The EGEA top associated SNPs were then tested for validation in an independent family study, the Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean asthma study (SLSJ), which included 253 French Canadian multigenerational families ascertained through 2 probands with asthma. 15

Asthma definition in probands was based on at least 2 of the following criteria: (1) a minimum of 3 clinic visits for acute asthma within 1 year, (2) 2 or more asthma-related hospital admissions within 1 year, or (3) steroid dependency.
In relatives asthma was defined by (1) a history of asthma (validated by a physician) or (2) asthma-related symptoms and bronchial hyperresponsiveness (see Table E1).
The definition of AR was similar to the one used in the EGEA study (see Table E1).

After QC of the genotypic data, the SLSJ analysis sample included 486 family members from 154 families with at least 1 genotyped offspring with AAR and 2 genotyped parents (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details).
In the third step we investigated whether the significant POO effects of SNPs on AAR were driven by differential DNAm levels measured in 40 SLSJ families by using CIT. 16
or all independent studies, ethical approval was obtained from the appropriate institutional ethic committees, and all subjects provided written informed consent.

The 3 data sets used for linkage analysis had been genotyped by using the same panel of 396 microsatellites at the Centre National de G enotypage (CNG, Evry, France) as part of our linkage analysis program. 17
After QC of the genotypic data, the analysis sample included a total of 2702 subjects belonging to 615 families with at least 2 genotyped sibs.

The discovery and replication association analyses were based on SNP data generated in the EGEA and SLSJ data sets by using the Illumina 610K array (Illumina, San Diego, Calif) at CNG as part of the European GABRIEL asthma consortium. 18
The same QC criteria were applied to both data sets, as described elsewhere. 19
The region analyzed for association included a total of 1233 genotyped SNPs covering the 6-Mb linkage region (95% CI defined by a 1.5-LOD decrease from the linkage peak).

Methylation levels at CpG sites were measured by using DNA from peripheral blood leukocytes in a subset of SLSJ subjects (n 5 167) by using the Infinium HumanMethylation450 BeadChip at Genome Quebec Innovation Centre (Montreal, Quebec, Canada). 11
After QC, a total of 159 subjects belonging to 40 nuclear SLSJ families were available for DNAm association analysis (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details).
Differential white cell counts (eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes) were measured by using an automated counter in SLSJ data.

The genome-wide multipoint linkage analysis for the 3 disease entities (asthma, AR, and AAR) used a model-free approach, the maximum likelihood binomial method that can be applied to the whole sibships, and was extended to account for the POO effect (maximum likelihood binomial method extended for imprinting). 20
Linkage was tested with and without the POO effect by using likelihood ratio tests (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details).

Association of the significant linkage region detected for AAR in the presence of the POO effect was investigated by using the Monte Carlo Pedigree Parental Asymmetry Test (MCPPAT) screening method applied to all SNPs covering this region.

This method tests for the asymmetry of transmission of the risk allele between the father and mother to heterozygous affected offspring (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details). 21
ssociation results reaching a critical threshold of 0.001 were validated by using a second method, the parent-of-origin likelihood ratio test (PO-LRT). 22

n addition to testing for the POO effect, this method allows distinguishing the POO effect from the maternal genotype effect on disease in affected offspring (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details).
It also provides estimates of these different effects, whereas the MCPPAT does not.

PO-LRT was only applied to MCPPAT-associated SNPs to reduce the multiple testing issue because it requires performing multiple model comparisons (POO effect only, maternal genotype effect only, or both POO and maternal genotype effects).
SNPs detected in EGEA families at a P value of .001
or less with both the MCPPAT and PO-LRT methods were followed up for replication in the SLSJ families and then analyzed in the pooled EGEA and SLSJ samples by using PO-LRT.
Significance of the POO effect was finally assessed by using a multiple testing corrected threshold that takes into account linkage disequilibrium between SNPs, as proposed by Li and Ji. 23

o determine whether the significant POO effect of SNPs on disease was driven by differential DNAm of paternal and maternal chromosomes, we carried out association analysis with DNAm levels at CpG sites lying close to the SNPs.

We tested for association of both paternally and maternally inherited alleles of AAR-associated SNPs and DNAm levels using a linear regression model adjusted for white cell type proportions (eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes) and applied to offspring of SLSJ families (see the Methods section in this article's Online Repository for details).
The DNAm levels at CpG sites that were found to be associated with AAR-associated SNPs were subsequently tested for association with disease (AAR) in offspring by using a logistic regression model.
In all regression models we used a robust sandwich estimation of variance to take into account familial dependencies.
At each step, a Bonferroni correction was applied to correct for the total number of tested CpG sites.
Finally, we carried out a CIT for DNAm levels associated with both SNPs and disease to establish the epigenetic mediation of the POO effect of SNP-AAR association.
This approach is based on a series of conditional association analyses described in the Methods section in this article's Online Repository. 16

If DNAm is a mediator of the relationship between SNP and AAR, the association between SNP and AAR is expected to decrease or even disappear when adjusting for DNAm levels in the regression model while the association between DNAm levels and disease remains significant.
The genome-wide linkage screen conducted for asthma, AR, and AAR in 1472 genotyped siblings (see Tables E2 and E3 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org)
showed significant evidence for linkage of the 4q35 region to AAR when taking into account the POO effect (Fig 1).

The LOD score reached 3.14 (P 5 7.2 3 10 25 ) at D4S426 when alleles were transmitted from the father, whereas there was only modest evidence for linkage when the POO effect was ignored (LOD, 1.44; P 5 .005).
No significant linkage with any other phenotype was detected (see Fig E2 and Table E4 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).

div.head: Association analysis with SNPs taking into account the POO effect

p.s: Of 1233 SNPs in the 4q35 linkage region, 5 (r 2 < 0.8) showed an association with AAR at a P value of .001
or less by using MCPPAT in 162 French EGEA families (see Table E5 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org),

and 2 of them were confirmed at the same level by using PO-LRT under the best-fitting model of paternally transmitted risk allele effect (Table I and see Table E6 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org). 22
Among these SNPs taken forward for replication in SLSJ families (see Table E5), rs10009104 showed nominally significant association with AAR (P 5 .02)
under the same paternal-origin effect model.
The EGEA and SLSJ pooled analysis improved evidence for this association (P 5 1.1 3 10 25 ) that achieved the multiple testing corrected threshold of 7.2 3 10 25 (Table I).
The ratio of effect for the paternally versus maternally inherited rs10009104-G allele (allelic frequency, 0.72) was 1.96 (95% CI, 1.43-2.70).

div.head: Association analysis with DNAm levels at CpG sites taking into account the POO effect

p.s: To assess whether association of the paternally inherited rs10009104-G allele with AAR was driven by differential DNAm of parental chromosomes, we tested for association between rs10009104 and DNAm levels at 24 CpG sites located in a 50-kb region around rs10009104 in 40 SLSJ families (159 subjects, see Table E7 in this article's Online Repository at www. jacionline.org).

The paternally inherited rs10009104-G allele was nominally associated with DNAm levels at 2 CpG sites, 1 of which met the significance threshold after Bonferroni correction (cg02303933: P 5 1.7 3 10 24 , Table II).
This CpG site was also associated with AAR (P 5 .006,
Table II).
These results were not influenced by adjustment on white cell-type proportions.
We used the CIT to assess whether DNAm levels at cg02303933 mediate the effect of the paternally inherited rs10009104-G allele on AAR (Fig 2).

In a regression model that included the effects of both DNAm and SNP on disease (AAR), we found that methylation levels at cg02303933 remained associated with AAR (P 5.03), whereas the paternally inherited G allele of rs10009104 did not (P 5 .28).
This demonstrates that the paternally inherited rs10009104-G allele effect on AAR is mediated by DNAm variations at this site.
Moreover, we estimated that the variance in AAR risk accounted for by the cg02303933 CpG site was 3 times higher than that explained by the rs10009104 SNP.
Using the UCSC genome browser (http://genome.ucsc.edu/),

we found that rs10009104 is located at 14 kb from the melatonin receptor 1A (MTNR1A) gene near a recombination hotspot and is in strong to moderate linkage disequilibrium with 6 SNPs upstream of MTNR1A or within MTNR1A intron 1 (D9 5 0.9, 0.60 < _ r 2 < _ 0.

The present study is the first to investigate genetic variants involved in the comorbidity of asthma and AR while accounting for the POO effect in both linkage and association analyses and seeking for methylation quantitative trait loci.
Through a positional cloning approach, we identified a paternally transmitted genetic variant (rs10009104-G allele) associated with AAR in the 4q35 linkage region.
We demonstrated that the effect of this paternally inherited variant on AAR was mediated by DNAm variation within the MTNR1A gene.

Evidence for association between rs10009104 and AAR rests on the results obtained from the large EGEA discovery family sample and validated in French Canadian families, an independent data set that was not part of the previous linkage study, plus strong improvement of results reaching statistical significance when combining these 2 samples.
Validation of this result was also obtained in EGEA through the use of different statistical methods, which provided concordant findings.
Our results were thus strengthened by validation at both the population and statistical methodology levels.
Moreover, stringent thresholds were used at all steps to correct for multiple testing.
The rs10009104 SNP associated with AAR is located near the linkage peak (1.6 Mb from D4S426) detected in the pooled analysis of 3 European data sets.
We checked that this SNP accounted for most of the linkage signal (see the Methods and Results sections in this article's Online Repository at www. jacionline.org for details).
][26] A maternal linkage between D4S426 and both atopy and total serum IgE levels has been reported in families of European ancestry. 26

Although this reported POO effect differs from that found in the present study, it should be noted that it was related to different phenotypes and that the published linkage study was not followed up by association analysis. 26
Nevertheless, the previous and current findings support the presence of the POO effect and potentially epigenetic mechanisms in the 4q35 region.
Existing methodologies investigating the POO effect require genotypic data of high quality in all family members (offspring and both parents).

To obtain a denser map of a surrounding region of rs10009104 and encompassing MTNR1A, we repeated association analyses (PO-LRT) using HapMap2 imputed SNPs (best guess genotype) with stringent postimputation QC criteria (r 2 > _ 0.9).

These analyses supported our original finding with additional signals located in the upstream region of MTNR1A and in intron 1 of that gene (P < 3 3 10 23 ), with the best signal still being detected at rs10009104 (results not shown).
The single GWAS conducted thus far for AAR, as well as the GWASs for asthma, AR, and allergy and asthma-related phenotypes, did not report any association with 4q35 genetic variants. 6,7
However, none of these studies had taken into account the POO effect.
Association analysis of rs10009104 with DNAm levels at CpG sites in the 4q35 region showed significant association with cg02303933.
This CpG site lies within a CTCF-binding site.
CTCF has a central role in chromatin organization and gene expression, and its implication in imprinting is well established. 27
isplaying properties of an insulator, CTCF mediates interactions between distant DNA sequences among which regulatory sequences acting as enhancer and promoter.
CTCF plays multiple roles in hematopoietic cell lineages, regulating early thymocyte development, 28 cell differentiation, and cytokine production in helper T cells. 29
Methylation at this site might disrupt the fixation of CTCF and could impair its regulatory function.
Nominal significant association of rs10009104 was also found with DNAm levels at cg02756176.
Interestingly, the same association has been reported in adipose tissues. 30
In addition, a part of the 4q35 linkage region spanning 4 kb, from 187.488 Mb to 187.492 Mb, and encompassing rs10009104 was described as an allele-specific methylation region in human embryos. 31
These reports strengthen the evidence for a broad differentially methylated region in 4q35.
The disease-associated CpG site (cg02303933) is located in intron 1 of the MTNR1A gene, which encodes a high-affinity G protein-coupled receptor for melatonin.

MTNR1A is an integral membrane protein that responds to a variety of extracellular stimuli and modulates several signal transduction pathways, among which are G i protein-adenylyl cyclase (cyclic AMP) and extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2, 2 pathways involved in inflammation regulation. 32
MTNR1A is expressed in numerous organs and cell types, including the lung and B and T cells.
MTNR1A appears to be a good candidate for AAR based on several lines of evidence.

Indeed, MTNR1A participates in the action of melatonin, which can have an important immunomodulatory effect in patients with allergic diseases, including antioxidant effects, and an action on T H 2 signaling pathways.

Notably, in experimental models melatonin administration regulates smooth muscle tone, attenuates airway inflammation and lung mucus production, and reduces proinflammatory cytokine levels in human bronchial epithelial cell lines. 33,34
Both melatonin secretion and MTNR1A expression are regulated in a circadian manner. 32
Interestingly, a circadian variation in asthma and AR symptoms is well described, with worsening symptoms overnight. 35
Moreover, the circadian cycle is known to be regulated by epigenetic mechanisms. 36

lthough the present linkage analysis included 3 different data sets totaling 615 families and the association study was performed in 2 data sets (for discovery and validation) totaling 316 families, additional replication of our findings might be desirable.
However, access to asthma family data sets with comparable study design, phenotype definitions, and genotyping is limited, especially in the GWAS era.

We did not find any 4q35 genetic variant associated with the expression (expression quantitative trait locus) of MTNR1A in blood and lung tissue (see the Results section in this article's Online Repository for details).
It should be noted that current expression quantitative trait locus databases report data without distinguishing the parental origin of the effect allele.
We examined DNAm, one of the epigenetic marks implicated in gene expression regulation, to explain the detected POO effect in the 4q35 region.
However, other epigenetic modifications could be investigated, such as histone modifications. 10
oreover, increase of CpG site density with a sequencing method might reveal additional CpG sites associated with AAR.

Further investigations of the 4q35 locus, such as biological experiments, will have the potential to validate methylation findings and improve our understanding of the genetic factors and epigenetic mechanisms underlying the risk of asthma plus rhinitis.
In conclusion, we identified that differential DNAm within MTNR1A mediates the effect of a paternally inherited genetic variant on the co-occurrence of asthma and AR.

The present study highlights the importance of integrating genetic and epigenetic data in family-based studies to uncover such imprinting mechanisms and therefore to identify new genes in complex diseases.

We thank all those who participated in the setting of the study and the various aspects of the examinations involved: interviewers; technicians for lung function testing and skin prick tests, blood sampling, and IgE determinations; coders; those involved in QC, data, and sample management; and all those who supervised the study in all EGEA centers.
We also thank the 3 CIC-INSERM facilities of Necker, Grenoble, and Marseille who supported the EGEA study and in which subjects were examined.
We are also grateful to the biobanks in Lille (CIC-INSERM) and at Annemasse (Etablissement franc ¸ais du sang), where EGEA biological samples are stored.

Establishing the epigenetic mediation of genetic risk: CIT applied with the paternally inherited rs10009104-G allele as the causal factor (G), DNAm levels at cg02303933 as a potential mediator (M), and asthma plus rhinitis as the outcome (Y).

Genetic distance is plotted on the x-axis, and LOD score is plotted on the y-axis.
73; see Fig E3 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).
cg02303933 is located in that intron in the north shore of a CpG island and at a 15-kb distance from rs10009104.

This CpG site lies in overlapping functional elements, including DNase I hypersensitivity clusters and CCCTCbinding factor (CTCF)-binding site (see Fig E4 in this article's Online Repository at www.jacionline.org).

p.s: d A differential DNA-methylated CpG site within MTNR1A mediates the effect of a paternally inherited genetic variant on the co-occurrence of asthma and AR.
d The variance in asthma and AR risk accounted for by this methylated CpG site was 3 times higher than that explained by the detected genetic variant.
d Examination of both DNAm profiles and SNP data bring better insight into epigenetic mechanisms, mediating the associations between genetic variants and complex diseases.
